wikipedia_page.main: Antony Genn (born 1971 in Sheffield, England) is a British musician formerly in Pulp.He also toured with Elastica in 1995–1996, playing keyboards. He is known for co-writing with Joe Strummer and forming The Mescaleros in 1999. Antony co-wrote and produced The Mescaleros first album Rock Art and the X-Ray Style. Antony was also guitarist and M.D of the band until his departure in 2000. He has been with The Hours since 2004.

response: * Antony Genn – bass (1988)
bar:Genn text:"Antony Genn"

In the mid-to-late 1990s, Strummer gathered top-flight musicians into a backing band he called the Mescaleros. Strummer and the band signed with Mercury Records, and released their first album in 1999, which was co-written with Antony Genn, called Rock Art and the X-Ray Style. A tour of England, Europe, and North America soon followed.
*Antony Genn – additional programming

Many of the band members were multi-instrumentalists. The original line up consisted of Strummer on vocals and guitar, Antony Genn on guitar, Scott Shields on bass, guitar and drums, Martin Slattery on keyboards and guitar, as well as flute and saxophone on select songs, Pablo Cook on various percussion instruments and Steve Barnard on drums, using his stage moniker "Smiley". Richard Flack was also employed to use effects and instruments.

The Mescaleros rose out of Strummer's work with Pablo Cook and Richard Norris.  The three of them originally came together to write the soundtracks for two short films, Tunnel of Love, and Question of Honour.  The song "Yalla Yalla" was originally written by this trio, and mixed by Antony Genn.  Once Genn was brought on board, a new song "Techno D-Day" was recorded, at which point Strummer, at the behest of Genn, began recording a new record.

The Mescaleros' first gig was in Antony Genn's hometown of Sheffield at The Leadmill on 5 June 1999. They toured extensively for the next six months, including playing the Glastonbury Festival, the U.S., and Europe.
Antony Genn currently fronts The Hours, a band that he and fellow Mescalero Martin Slattery formed in 2004.
* Antony Genn – guitar (1999–2000)
* Antony Genn - Loops (2), Strings (2)
*Antony Genn (The Mescaleros, The Hours)
*Antony Genn – keyboards (1995–1996; touring)

link_mentions.page: Rock Art and the X-Ray Style
response: Rock Art and the X-Ray Style is the debut album by Joe Strummer and the Mescaleros, released in 1999.  This album featured the band in its first incarnation: Joe Strummer and Antony Genn on guitar and vocals, Martin Slattery playing keyboards and guitar, Steve "Smiley" Barnard on drums, Pablo Cook on other percussion instruments, and Scott Shields on bass.  Richard Flack also did engineering on the album.

* Antony Genn - Guitar (1,3,4,6,7,8,10), Bass (1,3,6), Backing Vocals (1,4,6,7,8,10), Fresh Drum Re-Wire (1), Orphan Choir (3), Acoustic Guitar (5), Piano (6,10), Extra Re-Wire Beats (8), Synthesizer (10), Strings (10), Programming (10)
* Antony Genn - Mixing, Producer
He was in the band The Hours alongside Antony Genn from 2004 until 2007.  He has worked with a number of artists since then, as vocalist, multi-instrumentalist and composer.

Steve Mackey and Mark Webber, fellow band members from Pulp play on this record. Antony Genn, a former Pulp member, and Richard Hawley, who toured and performed, also play on the album. Candida Doyle has played on various tracks when performed live.
* Antony Genn – harmony vocal
The Hours are an English rock band, formed in 2004 by Antony Genn and Martin Slattery.

Antony Genn got his start as a 16-year-old joining Pulp and went on to play with Elastica and Joe Strummer and the Mescaleros.The Hours: Biography & History AllMusic. Retrieved 22 November 2018. He went on to co-write a number of songs with Robbie Williams, Josh Homme, Brian Eno, Ian Brown from The Stone Roses, Scott "Walker" Engel, Jarvis Cocker, Lee Hazlewood and others, along with writing and producing scores for film and television.
*Scotsman interview with Antony Genn
*Playlouder 'Class of 2007' interview with Antony Genn

link_mentions.page: Don't Let Him Waste Your Time
response: Richard Hawley plays electric guitar on the track, while Cocker's Pulp bandmate Steve Mackey plays bass. The track also features former Pulp member Antony Genn on backing vocals, and Martin Slattery of The Mescaleros on piano and saxophone.Don't Let Him Waste Your Time CD sleeve notes – RTRADSCD385
All tracks composed by Antony Genn and Martin Slattery; except where indicated

Themes of the album include ruminations on the celebrities that songwriters Antony Genn and Martin Slattery have known in their previous careers as musicians, such as on the title track; love songs such as "Love You More"; uplifting exhortations to achieve, such as in "Ali in the Jungle"; and references and metaphors related to football.
